prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Time justification: The observations proposed here are to detect the redshifted integrated CO 3-2 emission in these 10 below main-sequence massive z~2 galaxies. To get the highest sensitivity we propose to observe with the most compact configuration in band-3, and will smooth over the entire expected line-width. The sources are drawn from 3 different fields, and we group together sources in each field with similar integration time estimates to minimize overheads. We estimate the integration times required for this experiment using the molecular gas scaling relations for z=1=2 SFGs derived from our PHIBSS survey for galaxies on the main sequence (last column in Table 1). This scaling predicts at least 6σ detections of the integrated CO 3-2 line in the 3mm band (assuming vrot sin(i)~200-300 km/s) in on-source integration times ranging between 30 and 90 minutes. For the estimate we have adopted a constant, Milky Way CO 1-0 to molecular gas mass conversion factor (αCO =4.36 M8/(K km/s pc^2) and a CO 3-2 to 1-0 Rayleigh Jeans temperature ratio of 0.5, as determined by recent calibrations at both low and high-z (e.g. Carilli & Walter 2013). This choice is empirically justified for the massive, main-sequence population (logM*>10 for the galaxies here), and especially for this proposed high mass, near-solar metallicity sample (e.g. Bolatto et al. 2013).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Throughout cosmic time, the bulk of field star-forming galaxies (SFGs), which form a fairly tight sequence in stellar mass versus star formation rate (hereafter, "main-sequence"),grow by gas accretion/minor mergers and in-situ star formation until their stellar mass exceeds the Schechter mass, logMS*~11, at which point they rapidly shut down and join the red sequence. Why is this so? We propose to measure CO-based molecular gas fractions and gas depletion time scales of a statistically significant sample of massive (M*≥MS) z~2 SFGs that are below the main sequence and thus should be in the process of transitioning to the red sequence. The proposed observations, along with our other data of SFGs at z~1-2 above and on the main sequence, will test for two main proposed INTERNAL quenching mechanisms. Rapidly dropping gas fractions below the main sequence would favor AGN feedback driving the shutdown. Rapidly increasing depletion time scales would favor morphological quenching, where the buildup of a massive bulge/spheroidal component acts to stabilize the galaxies against global gravitational instabilities,as a key player.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
